title: AB 1685
content: The people of California enact the following. Section 43016 of the Health and Safety Code is amended to impose civil penalties for violations of emission control laws, with a maximum penalty of $37,500 per violation. Violations related to portable fuel containers or small off-road engines may incur a penalty of up to $500 per unit. Manufacturers or distributors may be required to pay the penalty and ensure compliance with emission control laws to continue selling regulated products in California. The state board adjusts maximum penalties for inflation based on the California Consumer Price Index, exempt from the Administrative Procedure Act. Penalties collected are deposited in the Air Pollution Control Fund. Section 43151 prohibits the sale, import, or use of uncertified motor vehicles or engines in California. The article exempts certain vehicle acquisitions such as replacements for damaged or stolen vehicles, vehicles transferred by inheritance or court decree, and vehicles sold after a specific legislative amendment date if previously registered in the state. Section 43154 of the Health and Safety Code is amended to impose a civil penalty of up to $37,500 for violating emission control laws. Manufacturers may also be required to pay the penalty and make vehicles compliant for continued sale in the state. The state board may impose a civil penalty of up to $10,000 on dealers violating emission control laws, with adjustments for inflation. Penalties are enforced in superior court and deposited into the Air Pollution Control Fund. Section 43211 of the Health and Safety Code is amended to impose civil penalties on manufacturers who sell new motor vehicles in California that fail to meet emission standards. The penalties can reach up to $37,500 per violation and $5,000 per zero-emission vehicle credit. The state board will adjust the maximum penalty for inflation based on the California Consumer Price Index, with penalties deposited into the General Fund. Section 43212 of the Health and Safety Code is amended to impose civil penalties on manufacturers or distributors who do not comply with emission standards or test procedures. The penalty can reach up to $37,500 per vehicle sold in California that does not meet the standards. Any penalty recovered will be deposited into the Air Pollution Control Fund. The state board may order a manufacturer of motor vehicles to comply with emissions configuration. Compliance may be required for continued sale in California. Penalties recovered will go to the Air Pollution Control Fund.
